title: C88-1044

sentences.text: This paper presents necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English and discusses implications for current discourse processing algorithms .
We examine a broad range of texts to show how the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions is genre dependent .
This research is part of a larger study of anaphoric expressions , the results of which will be incorporated into a natural language generation system .

Entity-this_paper.label: This paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents research on the necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English, exploring their implications for discourse processing algorithms and their genre-dependent distribution.

Entity-this_research.label: This research
Entity-this_research.description: This research refers to the investigation of necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English, which is part of a broader study on anaphoric expressions aimed at enhancing natural language generation systems.

Entity-implication_for_current_discourse.label: implications for current discourse processing algorithms
aliases: implications for current discourse processing algorithms
Entity-implication_for_current_discourse.description: The term 'implications for current discourse processing algorithms' refers to the potential effects and considerations that the findings regarding demonstrative expressions in English may have on the design and functionality of algorithms used for understanding and processing discourse in natural language processing systems.

mentions.local_name: implications for current discourse processing algorithms

Entity-necessary_and_sufficient_conditio.label: necessary and sufficient conditions
Entity-necessary_and_sufficient_conditio.description: Necessary and sufficient conditions refer to the specific criteria that must be met for the correct use of demonstrative expressions in English, as outlined in the context of discourse processing algorithms.

Entity-genre_dependent.label: genre dependent
Entity-genre_dependent.description: The term 'genre dependent' refers to the variability in the distribution and usage of demonstrative expressions in English, which is influenced by the specific genre of the text being analyzed.

Entity-the_distribution_of_demonstrative.label: the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions
aliases: the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions
Entity-the_distribution_of_demonstrative.description: The distribution of demonstrative forms and functions refers to the varying usage patterns and roles of demonstrative expressions in English across different genres of text.

mentions.local_name: the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions

Entity-demonstrative_form_and_function.label: demonstrative forms and functions
Entity-demonstrative_form_and_function.description: The term 'demonstrative forms and functions' refers to the various linguistic expressions and their roles in conveying reference and meaning in English, particularly how their usage varies across different genres of text.

Entity-demonstrative_form.label: demonstrative forms
Entity-demonstrative_form.description: Demonstrative forms refer to linguistic expressions in English, such as 'this', 'that', 'these', and 'those', which indicate specific entities in discourse and vary in usage depending on the genre of the text.

Entity-genre.label: genre
Entity-genre.description: In this context, 'genre' refers to the category or classification of texts that influences the distribution and usage of demonstrative expressions in English.

Entity-a_larger_study_of_anaphoric_expre.label: a larger study of anaphoric expressions
aliases: a larger study of anaphoric expressions
Entity-a_larger_study_of_anaphoric_expre.description: A larger study of anaphoric expressions refers to an extensive research initiative that investigates the use and distribution of anaphoric expressions, particularly demonstrative forms, across various texts, with the aim of enhancing natural language generation systems.

mentions.local_name: a larger study of anaphoric expressions

Entity-function.label: functions
Entity-function.description: In this context, 'functions' refers to the roles and purposes that demonstrative expressions serve in different genres of text.

Entity-text.label: texts
Entity-text.description: The term 'texts' refers to various written materials analyzed in the study to investigate the genre-dependent distribution of demonstrative expressions in English.

Entity-demonstrative_expression.label: demonstrative expressions
Entity-demonstrative_expression.description: Demonstrative expressions are linguistic constructs used to indicate specific entities in discourse, typically through terms like 'this', 'that', 'these', and 'those'.

Entity-the_result.label: the results
Entity-the_result.description: The results refer to the findings from a larger study on anaphoric expressions that will be utilized in the development of a natural language generation system.

Entity-a_broad_range_of_text.label: a broad range of texts
Entity-a_broad_range_of_text.description: A broad range of texts refers to various written works across different genres that are analyzed to understand the usage and distribution of demonstrative expressions in English.

Entity-discourse_processing_algorithm.label: discourse processing algorithms
Entity-discourse_processing_algorithm.description: Discourse processing algorithms are computational models designed to analyze and interpret the structure and meaning of discourse in natural language, facilitating understanding of how language is used in context.

Entity-anaphoric_expression.label: anaphoric expressions
Entity-anaphoric_expression.description: Anaphoric expressions are linguistic constructs that refer back to previously mentioned entities or concepts within a discourse, serving to maintain coherence and avoid repetition.

Entity-english.label: English
Entity-english.description: English is a West Germanic language that is the primary language spoken in England and widely used as a global lingua franca.

Entity-natural_language_generation_syste.label: natural language generation system
Entity-natural_language_generation_syste.description: A natural language generation system is a type of software that uses artificial intelligence to automatically produce human-like text based on input data.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written work that presents research findings, theories, or arguments, typically in an academic or scholarly context.

Entity-research.label: research
Entity-research.description: Research refers to a systematic investigation or study aimed at discovering and interpreting facts, theories, or principles in a specific field.

summary: This paper presents necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English and discusses implications for current discourse processing algorithms . We examine a broad range of texts to show how the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions is genre dependent . This research is part of a larger study of anaphoric expressions , the results of which will be incorporated into a natural language generation system .

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is offering, displaying, or introducing information, ideas, or findings to the audience, which is represented by the object. It implies a communicative act where the subject conveys content that is relevant or significant to the object, often in a formal or structured manner.

Predicate-discusses.label: discusses
Predicate-discusses.description: The predicate 'discusses' indicates that the subject engages in a detailed examination or conversation about the object, providing insights, analysis, or commentary on the topic represented by the object. It implies an exploration of ideas, arguments, or findings related to the object, facilitating understanding or further inquiry.

Predicate-are_used_in.label: are used in
Predicate-are_used_in.description: The predicate 'are used in' establishes a functional relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is employed or applied within the context or framework represented by the object. This suggests that the subject plays a role or serves a purpose in the domain specified by the object.

Predicate-show_how_the_distribution_of.label: show how the distribution of
Predicate-show_how_the_distribution_of.description: The predicate 'show how the distribution of' serves to illustrate or explain the patterns, variations, or arrangements of a particular element or category within a specified subject. It connects the subject to the object by indicating that the subject will provide insights or evidence regarding the presence, frequency, or organization of the object in a given context.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or relationship between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject possesses a certain quality, characteristic, or state represented by the object, thereby defining or categorizing the subject in relation to that object.

Predicate-is_genre_dependent.label: is genre dependent
Predicate-is_genre_dependent.description: The predicate 'is genre dependent' indicates that the subject's characteristics, behaviors, or interpretations are influenced by or vary according to different genres. This relationship suggests that the subject cannot be fully understood or analyzed without considering the specific genre context in which it operates, as the genre may dictate certain conventions, styles, or meanings that affect the subject.

Predicate-is_part_of.label: is part of
Predicate-is_part_of.description: The predicate 'is part of' indicates a relationship where the subject is a component, element, or subset of the object, which represents a larger whole or context. This connection implies that the subject contributes to or is included within the broader scope defined by the object.

Predicate-will_be_incorporated_into.label: will be incorporated into
Predicate-will_be_incorporated_into.description: The predicate 'will be incorporated into' indicates a future action where the subject is expected to be integrated or included within the framework, structure, or system represented by the object. This suggests a process of assimilation or merging, where the subject contributes to or enhances the capabilities or functionalities of the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates a hierarchical relationship where the subject represents a specific concept or entity that falls under a more general category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the subject is a subset or a more detailed instance of the broader concept, which encompasses a wider range of related ideas or entities.
